dict.string: We come from dust; we return to dust.
An exclamation used by conjurers when performing tricks.
Ask a silly question and you'll get a silly answer.
Not facing reality; in a dream-world.
Older people should be given precedence over the younger and, by implication, more beautiful. This is normally used jocularly, often by the older person in order to flatter the younger.
To help and encourage, usually in the commission of a crime or anti-social act.
Everyone wants success but many lack the self-discipline to become successful.
All cats love fish but hate to get their paws wet.
A large, possibly exorbitant, amount of money.
Pertaining to, or having an interest in, the arts - often pretentiously and affectedly so.
Said in preparation of getting underway, especially of a ship.
Excited, in high spirits; in eager expectation.
As black as a Newgate's knocker.
A restaurant advertising slogan usually followed by a price.
The name of the well-known Christian hymn, written by Henry Francis Lyte in 1847. A plea for God to be always present, in one's life and through death.
It is easy to give advice, but hard to act.
Full of verve and vitality; more recently - with many features or attributes.
(The) apple doesn't fall far from the tree.
The supposed inscription at the entrance to Hell.
Abandon hope all ye who enter here.
Often applied to the British 'kitchen sink' playwrights of the 1950s. Also anyone, particularly young men obviously, who rails against the establishment.
The victim of a trick played on April 1st, or the trick itself.
When you're away from something, you miss it more.
Absence makes the heart grow fonder.
Highly excited, or under the influence of drink or drugs.
To foreshadow a successful outcome, indicated by some circumstance or event.
As fit as a butcher's dog.
Be sure to take breaks from work and do something entertaining.
All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.
A state of confusion and disorder, or of disagreement between parties.
Two things that are very different from each other.
As different as chalk and cheese.
Completely mad. This is now commonly understood to mean crazy, although the original meaning is unclear and may have meant annoyed.
As pure as the driven snow.
Extremely fine, that is, delicate and slender.
Things sometimes go wrong, despite our best efforts.
What matters is what something is, not what it is called.
Arose by any other name would smell as sweet.
As cute as a bug's ear.
In accord with the highest authority; in accord with a strict set of rules.
Entirely or very brown; often referring to a suntanned skin.
Anact which is accepted legally as being outside human control.
Aburden which some unfortunate person has to carry.
(An) apple a day keeps the doctor away.
Set aside an irreconcilable difference in order to maintain a civil dialogue.
Everything, or everyone, is accounted for.

To have 'another think coming' is to be greatly mistaken. The phrase is usually spoken by an antagonist as 'you have another think coming'; the implication being that one will shortly be obliged to adopt a different viewpoint, either by the presentation of indisputable evidence, or by force.
Asure test, giving an incontestable result.
All things having been taken into account.
A stance, with the hands on the hips and elbows directed outwards.
In a direct line, without any of the detours caused by following a road.
A meditation on the fragility of life.
Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him, Horatio.
A small child. Also applied to small dogs.
As alike as two peas in a pod.
Embracing all classes or categories without exception.
Children are in many regards like their parents.
(The) apple never falls far from the tree.
As mad as a March hare.
From the Italian, literally translated as 'in the fresh'. In English, used to mean either 'in the open air' or, where specifically related to mural painting, 'on fresh plaster'.
Originally meaning the central aperture of the eye. Figuratively it is something, or more usually someone, cherished above others.
A dynamic, macho type of man.
Oddor unusual. Also used to mean homosexual.
As queer as a nine bob note.
Somethingthat can supply a sure victory when revealed.
'To aid memory' - a literal translationfrom the French.
Children will become like older generations.
As the old cock crows, so crows the young.
The translation into Latin of part of a quotation by the Greek 'Father of Medicine' - Hippocrates.
As thick as two short planks.
In a state of confusion and disorder.
Acronyms are words which are formed from the initial letters of other words.
The act of greeting or sometimes of farewell by making a kissing gesture into the air while brushing cheeks - or in a near miss.
Clumsy, unable to hold things steadily in one's hands. 'All fingers and thumbs' is how we might describe ourselves during a temporary loss of manual dexterity.
All things come to he who waits.
Not everything that is shiny and superficially attractive is valuable.
All that glitters is not gold.
It's better to avoid disputes with stupid people.
Better flatter a fool than fight him.
One who works in anonymity in an organization while others take on more public roles.
Act in a boastful, self-promoting manner.
Something difficult seems easier when it is done voluntarily.
(A) burden of one's own choice is not felt.
Always give an excuse, even if it's a poor one.
(A) bad excuse is better than none.

Christians who affirm their renewed and strengthened commitment to their religion are called 'born again'. To be born again is to be 'born of the spirit'; the first birth being the physical birth of the flesh.
To be 'caught/got/held by the short hairs', or in the UK equivalent '... by the short and curlies', is to be trapped by an opponent in a position one can't easily escape from.
Outside the range of what is normally considered believable.
It's better to have a lesser but certain advantage than the possibility of a greater one that may come to nothing.
(A) bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Drinking to excess in a short space of time.
Interactions that occur between black people, notably crime that is perpetrated by one black person against another.
Nickname for New Orleans, USA, referringto the easy-going, laid back attitude to life that jazz musicians and local residents indulge in there.
To hang a bell around a cat's neck to provide a warning. Figuratively, the expression refers to any task that is difficult or impossible to achieve.
The method of appointing people to positions based on rotation rather than on merit.
People with important similarities seek out one another's company, often to the exclusion of others.
Birds of a feather flock together.
Disintegrated into small fragments by a sudden impact or explosion.
To prevaricate and avoid coming to the point.
In difficulty, faced with two dangerous alternatives.
Between the Devil and the deep blue sea.
The most carefully prepared plans may go wrong.
(The) best laid schemes of mice and men.
The remedy might be bitter, but the cure might be wonderful.
Bitter pills may have blessed effects.
There is a wealth of knowledge in books.
(A) book holds a house of gold.
Friendships can be rebuilt after a dispute but will never be as strong as before.
(A) broken friendship may be soldered but will never be sound.
Responsibility is not passed on beyond this point.
Breathing that is subdued because of some emotion or difficulty.
Someone who criticizes from the sidelines.
To defy or go beyond what is believable.
An oath, alluding to mayhem and bloodshed.
Back to the beginning, to start again.
Fail, due to being unable to choose between two alternatives.
The father of an infant who is not married to or in an exclusive relationship with the mother.
To have experienced the topic under discussion, to the point of boredom or complacency.
A person who is wrong will eventually be right about something.
(A) broken watch is right two times a day.
The agent of ruin or woe.
Turn to peaceful pursuits and away from war.

Aninfirm or failing person or thing - unable to function properly. Originallythis referred to soldiers who had lost arms and legs and had to be carried by others. More recently it has been used to denounce a failing organisation or scheme and is less often applied to people.
An important person. Now usually spelled as single word, 'bigwig'.
If you are in a bad situation or do not have much to offer you must be content with whatever help you can get.
With a furrowed or prominent brow, or worried expression. Formerly, with large or bushy eyebrows.
Beelzebub has a devil for a sideboard.
A list of things that a person wants to experience or achieve before they die.
To settle your differences with an adversary.
Somethingthat spoils the view or ruins a previously comfortable situation.
To study hard, usually in preparation for a test.
Someone who constantly makes threats rarely carries them out.

Ostensibly, a warning that something dangerous is imminent. In reality, this is usually said with comic intent. The thing being warned of is more likely to be mildly unwelcome than actually dangerous; for example, "That fierce librarian was asking about your overdue books - be afraid, be very afraid.".
Talk repetitively and boringly about something.
Making a mistake or a false assumption in something you are trying to achieve.
Anobsessive and dangerous female, in pursuit of a lover who has spurned her.
Acomplete surprise, likea bolt of lightning from a clear blue sky.
The distribution of power between nations in such a way that no single state has dominanceover the others.
A sales model that utilizes both traditional stores bricks and Internet trading clicks.
To be at someone's beck and call is to be entirely subservient to them; to be responsive to their slightest request.
The source of abundant fun and enjoyment.
Afist. Thefives are the five fingers.
Various meanings, including 'making an emergency parachute escape from an aeroplane' and 'ladling water from a boat'.
A person's background or education will eventually show.
A disparaging term for an accountant, or anyone excessively concerned with statistical records or accounts.
A place where valuables are stored, especially the clothes, linen, etc., that a woman might store in preparation for her marriage. Literally, the lowest drawer of a chest of drawers.
An unpopular person will always return to the place he came from.
People should not be judged by their appearance.
(A) black plum is as sweet as a white.
So it is, but this proverb hasn't to do with measures of viscosity. The expression, meaning that family bonds are closer than those of outsiders.
Give up an attempt at something after losing one's nerve.
To thelimit of one's efforts - to the last extremity.

Somethingor someone that returns after a period of obscurity or absence. It is normally applied to things that that were thought fondly of previously and are making a welcome return - particularly pop songs.
Beauty is the wisdom of women.Wisdom is the beauty of men.
Better to light a candle than curse the darkness.
A practical joke. Also a concealed and possibly lethal trap.
It is preferable to have something sure now than the possibility of something better later.
Better an egg today than a hen tomorrow.
Areturn to previously held values of decency.
A set meal provided at a reduced price.
Said to actors for good luck before they go on stage, especially on an opening night.
The most attractive woman at a social gathering.
Narrowly; barely. Usually used in regard to a narrow escape from a disaster.
By the skin of your teeth.
A difficult position from which it is unlikely one can escape.
It's better not to be taught at all than to be taught badly.
To earn money, particularly for one's family; to be successful, especially financially successful.
A game, in which a blindfolded player tries to catch others.
Fall to the ground, wounded or dead.
The paying audience at a venue with seating, usually a theatre or cinema.
The seemingly most respectable people are quiet often scoundrels; Evil people often act innocently.
Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep's clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.
It's better to deal with someone difficult but familiar than change and risk dealing with somebody worse.
Better the devil you know than the devil you don't know.
A prize given to make fun of the loser in a contest or game.
Shy or reluctant to do something. Here 'backward' means shy or unwilling; 'come forward' means present oneself into view.
A bad parent does not raise good children.
(A) bad tree does not yield good apples.
Ostentatious, over-the-top jewellery or dress. Often used to demonstrate the wearer's wealth.
To be captivated; to be held spellbound by pleasing qualities.
To work late into the night. Originally this was by the light of an oil lamp or candle. More recently, the phrase is used figuratively, alluding back its use before electric lighting.
Adisreputable or disgraced member of a family.
A secret; something that only the speaker and the listener should know.
Between you, me and the bedpost.
Make sure all your debts are paid before you start offering help to others.
Be just before you are generous.
Born within the sound of Bow Bells.
A phrase that refers to coy explanations of basic information about sex and reproduction to children.
To die, particularly in an accident or military action.
The best way to get something done is to do it yourself.
(The) best helping hand is at the end of your sleeve.
A day on which one's hair seems unmanageable. Also extended to mean a day when everything seems to go wrong.
Be careful in the choice of the people you associate with.
Better be alone than in bad company.
The dark interior of the earth.
A person born during the temporary peak in the birth-rate that occurred in several countries following WWII, notably the USA and the UK.
A thing to be achieved will be done in a straightforward way, but if it cannot, then it will be achieved by any means necessary.
On the whole; generally speaking; all things considered.
Someone or something that disappoints expectations.
Born with a silver spoon in one's mouth.
Asea trip from England to continental Europe to buy cheap drink.
In a very short time; suddenly.
Before you could say Jack Robinson.
Play on words, based on 'Bill Stickers...' notices.
The phrase that denoted excommunication from the Catholic church.
Hard work and effort in difficult circumstances.
Brag is a good Dog, but Holdfast is a better.
You don't have to pay for what is important: happiness, friendship, good health.
(The) best things in life are free.
Someone who is important but only within a limited area of influence.
Big fish in a small pond.
It is often better to escalate your commitment rather than starting over with something new.
It's better to stop and accept a small loss than continue and risk losing everything.
Better lose the saddle than the horse.
To arrive or do something later than expected isn't good, but it is better than not at all.
To break down social formality and stiffness.
The aim for perfection or mastery might be in the way of progress.
Better is the enemy of good.
Be careful not to destroy the source of your income or welfare.
Better to drink the milk than to eat the cow.
Feelings of depression or anxiety, experienced by some mothers following childbirth.
Refuse to confront or acknowledge a problem.
Bury your head in the sand.
A 20th century slang term, meaning wife.
Blaming tools for bad workmanship is an excuse for lack of skill.
Place a bet on all the horses in a race, except one.
A name used by Christians to denote Jesus Christ.
Prim and proper, with a cool demeanour.
Butter wouldn't melt in his mouth.
A type of cuisine that combines both meat and seafood especially lobster and steak, or restaurants that serve such cuisine.

An approach to organisation or planning that is built up from basic details rather than from a guiding principal or theory. It is a form of organisation often associated with the democratic involvement of many individuals rather than one governed by an individual or small group.
A person who often threatens rarely carries out his threats.
Expand your mind by use of hallucinatory drugs.
But, for my own part, it was Greek to me.
'Be quiet'. Also, since the introduction of car seat belts - an injunction to fasten one's belt.
You will avoid an activity which has given you a bad experience for the rest of your life.
A name playfully applied to someone who fails to catch a ball or lets something slip from their fingers.
By means of; as a result of - especially by the means of force.
Be swift to hear, slow to speak.
Sweep a woman off her feet with a romantic gesture.
In difficulty, faced with a choice between two unsatisfactory options.
Between a rock and a hard place.
A good night's sleep may help us find an answer to our problem.
(The) best advice is found on the pillow.
A style of blues music, with close links to jazz forms like ragtime and stride, usually played on the piano.
The blood that which flows in the veins of old and aristocratic families.
It's better to be the leader of a small group than a subordinate in a bigger one.
Better be the head of a dog than the tail of a lion.
Behind every great man there's a great woman.
In the 18th century this was a dish of fried meat and cabbage. Nowadays it is more often fried potatoes and other vegetables, usually greens.
This is one of those rare phrases in which the meaning is more debated than the origin.

'Bob's your uncle' is an archetypically English phrase and is so familiar here for it to have spawned jokey variants. As 'take the Mickey' has an extended alternative 'extract the Michael', 'Bob's your uncle' is sometimes extended to 'Robert's your auntie's husband'. People in other English speaking countries won't be so familiar with the phrase, so I'll give some examples that may explain the meaning.
A sexually explicit romantic novel; usually in a historical setting and always with a plot involving the seduction of the heroine.
Anordeal or martyrdom. More recently, a soldier's first experience of battle.
Expression of excitement when seeing the object of one's romantic affections.
Accept the inevitable impending hardship and endure the resulting pain with fortitude.
It's better to be too careful than to be careless and regret it later.
Unacceptable; outside agreed standards of decency.
The difference between the value of the imports and exports that a nation makes.
Better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all.
Literal meaning - the perception of beauty is subjective.
Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.
A notional mark of achievement or kudos for performing some creditable act.
Uninformed and incompetent people leading others who are similarly incapable.
People tend to circulate bad news very quickly accidents, illness, etc.
A sound of contempt or derision, made by blowing through closed lips, usually with the tongue protruding.
Start again on a new design or plan after the failure of an earlier attempt.
To live at a hectic pace.
Burn the candle at both ends.
A weariness of and diminishing public response to frequent requests for charity.
To attempt to gain favour or ingratiate oneself, by officious courtesy or flattery.
Someone who is skilful at playing or manipulating cards, or one who makes a living by cheating at cards.
Amember of the upper classes - usually male.
Astate of intestinal disorder, usually accompanied by a rumbling stomach; for example, 'butterflies in the stomach'.
A change in routine is often as refreshing as a break or a holiday.
(A) change is as good as a rest.
To emerge or occur incidentally or unexpectedly.
To blush or turn red in the face.
To succeed; to come up to expectations.
The military order Havoc! was a signal given to the English military forces in the Middle Ages to direct the soldiery in Shakespeare's parlance 'the dogs of war' to pillage and chaos.
Cry havoc and let slip the dogs of war.
A paradox in which the attempt to escape makes escape impossible.
Confidence spills over to your coworkers.
Something bad that is called good out of politeness or timidity.
The trading policy that states a company's keenness to be seen to put the customer first.
When you are busy working, you avoid temptation.

There has always been some muddling up of the words overestimate and underestimate. The use of the negative in the expressions 'can't be over/underestimated' makes it easy to slip up. Also, the fact that, when you use either phrase, the context of what you are saying usually makes your meaning clear. Many speakers and the people they are speaking to just don't bother to check.
Can't be overestimated/Can't be underestimated - which one to use?.

Certain. This term has been used in many ways, all with different but related meanings; for example, 'absolutely sure or safe', 'completely dependable', 'sure in one's own mind', etc. The common thread through all of these is certainty.
Be restless and impatient to commence; especially during an unwelcome delay.
A box-like shape which is made by from twisting a loop of string around their fingers. It is usually played by two players, although some variations may be played by one.
The colloquial name for the conservative and discriminatory attitudes held by some sections of the British police forces.
A question addressed to someone who is inexplicably silent.
A slang term for the male genitalia.
Get to the point - leaving out unnecessary preamble.
Children should be seen and not heard.
If the atmosphere is clear, frost may form.
Fall over or fail at some venture.
To chat, in an aimless manner.
A person or thing that derives from the source or parentage.
Turbulent times wait just around the corner when it is calm.
In a state of exuberant elation.
A distraction technique used to combat insomnia.
A display of coldness or indifference, intended to wound.
Literal meaning - a person or thing that is viewed more with sadness than with anger.
(A) countenance more in sorrow than in anger.
A realm of fanciful or impractical, idealistic notions.
To get to know or understand something.

Originally a term from competitive rowing referring to an obvious gap between the leading boat and those following. In more recent years it has been used allusively to mean the discernible distance between the ideologies of two political parties.
To 'get cold feet' is to become disheartened or timid, losing one's previous enthusiasm or courage.
Try any route to get out of a desperate situation, no matter how unlikely it is to succeed.
A form of sofa with a backrest at one end only.
We should not waste time on trivial aspects of a matter and neglect the essential matter itself.
Catch not a shadow and lose the substance.
The biggest challenges in life brings out the best in people, as they rise to face the adversity.
Cometh the hour, cometh the man.
A perceived grievance or sense of inferiority.
To weep crocodile tears is to put on an insincere show of sorrow.
A person shows their competence or ability when difficulties arise.
(A) calm sea does not make a skilled sailor.
Good practical sense. The natural intelligence that is believed to be available to all rational people.
Usually translated from the Latin as 'I think, therefore I am'.
To do something pointless and superfluous.
The deliberate distorting of a firm's financial accounts, often with the aim of avoiding the payment of tax.
A film with characterization and story-lines that appeal especially to women.
Bad deeds or words return to discomfort their perpetrator.
If Google's search records are anything to go by, more people visit this site looking for the little used phrase 'carpe diem' than they do for any other phrase.
To complete something well or successfully, especially in circumstances in which it isn't expected.
A clean body is just as important as a pure soul.
Adopt an aggressive or antagonistic bearing.
A story or situation in which the main consideration is one of suspense.
Neither children nor fools know that it is sometimes advantageous to lie.
Children and fools tell the truth.
The sudden and complete withdrawal from an addictive substance and/or the physiological effects of such a withdrawal. Also, predominantly in the U.S.A., plain speaking.
A general term of disapproval, of something that is troublesome or a nuisance.
Apublicity campaign, usually by politicians, that attempts to attract supportersby emphasizing their charisma or trustworthiness.
There is not much chance of that [thing], welcome though it would be.
Chance would be a fine thing.
A group is not stronger than its weakest member.
(A) chain is only as strong as its weakest link.
A scene of disorder; a ruin; a mess.
To be caught red-handed is to be caught in the act of committing a misdemeanour, with the evidence there for all to see.
Inquisitiveness can lead one into dangerous situations.
Crammed so tightly together as to prevent movement.
Concerned with, or characteristic of espionage or intrigue, especially in the context of drama.
An awkward, unsophisticated rustic; a clown.
Disadvantage yourself in order to do harm to an adversary.
Cut off your nose to spite your face.
Cats can survive many accidents because they land on their feet without injury. Nine lives = 3 years to play, 3 years to stray, 3 years to stay.
'Cor blimey' is an exclamation of surprise.
A reference to unwanted sexual intercourse - specifically advice to an unwilling wife when sexually approached by her husband.
Close your eyes and think of England.
The sound that heralds the day of the Last Judgment, when God will decree the fates of all men according to the good and evil of their earthly lives.
If you come to visit too often, your host will be less pleased to see you.
Used to describe the contemporary culture of the United Kingdom, primarily during the 1990s.
The catchphrase used to invite audience members to the stage to become contestants in game shows.
Close contact with, especially in a military context - close contact with the enemy.
Slight consolation or encouragement in the face of a reverse.
Side by side; in close or intimate proximity.
A type of slang in which a words are replaced by a words or phrases they rhyme with.
If you learn when to keep silent you will avoid trouble.
The name of a salad typically consisting of cos lettuce, garlic, croutons and anchovies, dressed with olive oil, lemon juice and parmesan cheese.
The translation from the French is "look for/seek the woman". It is used when a man behaves unusually or gets into a quarrel or other difficulty and the reason for it is sought.
Originally, a utensil for cutting shaped pieces out of dough. More recently, characterising a lack of originality.
To make a full disclosure; to confess.

Inaccurately transmitted gossip. 'Chinese whispers' refers to a sequence of repetitions of a story, each one differing slightly from the original, so that the final telling bears only a scant resemblance to the original.
Fall just short of a successful outcome and get nothing for your efforts.
The more dressed up a man is, the more influential he is.
Sit down to eat - similar in meaning to the British term 'tuck in'.
Mere formal signs of being an authority does not make you one.
(A) cat may look at a king.
The appeal of nature in the raw.
The amount of carbon dioxide CO2 emitted during an industrial or domestic process; a measure of how that process contributes toward global warming.
To speak plainly - to describe something as it really is.
A proverb that expresses the overriding demands of taking care of one's family, before caring for others.
The meaning of this proverbial saying is self evident.
Don't let the bastards grind you down.
Don't waste time taking precautions when the damage has already been done.
Don't shut the stable door after the horse has bolted.
Times goes by very quickly when you are happyand very slowly when you are sad.
(A) day of sorrow is longer than a month of joy.
Thought to refer to mental and emotional disorder or spiritual torment as opposed to bodily pain.
Diseases of the soul are more dangerous than those of the body.
A paid day's work in which the employee is allowed to stay at home for rest and relaxation.
Being cautious is better than to merely be courageous.
Discretion is the better part of valor.
A false and exaggerated belief about one's status or importance.
Falling down ill or dead in large numbers.
Make a deduction from a person's pay.
A proverbial phrase indicating that those who lag behind will receive no aid.
Don't pay someone to do a task and then do it yourself.
Don't keep a dog and bark yourself.
Don't give up in the face of adversity.
Don't do things in a needlessly laborious way; don't pursue a goal already accomplished.
If you are prepared to face a problem or difficulty, it will be easier to deal with.
Don't reject an idea entirely because parts of it are bad.; Someone who is absolutely right about parts of an idea, can still be absolutely wrong about another part of it.
Don't throw the baby out with the bathwater.
Don't do something yourself that causes your own downfall.
Don't dig your grave with our own knife and fork.
Impending trouble or other bad consequences following from one's actions.
Do unto others as you would have them do to you.
A short growth of beard, aimed to affect a rugged masculine or deliberately unkempt appearance.
Don't offer advice to someone who has more experience than oneself.
Don't try to teach your Grandma to suck eggs.
Do not take action to spite others that will harm you more than them.
Don't cut off your nose to spite your face.
The evil and malevolent aspect of human personality or society, often referred to in a lighthearted or comic context.
Someone who emerges to prominence; being previously little known.
A person who holds stubbornly to a minority view, in defiance of the circumstances.
The details of a plan, while seeming insignificant, may contain hidden problems that threaten its overall feasibility.
The most difficult moment is just before a problem is solved.
(The) darkest hour is just before dawn.
A small and temporary recovery in a financial market following a large fall.
A figure of speech in which a phrase can be understood in two ways - one of them risqué. Commonly used to convey sexual puns.
All people are equal when they die.
Don't bother to pursue your application further.
Don't call us, we'll call you.
Raise your hat in acknowledgement of or deference to another.
What you do to me, I can do to you.
People of the same background have the same behaviour.
Dogs of the same street bark alike.
To fail to recall a memory or fail in some speculative effort.
Dismissed from army service to the sound of a drum.
People who have no work, or are idle, often get into trouble.
(The) devil makes work for idle hands.
Harvest predictions are made according to the weather.
(A) dry March, a wet April and a cool May fill barn and cellar and bring much hay.
The darkest hour is the time when bad events are at their worst and most dispiriting.
To wait upon someone in an overly assiduous or sycophantic manner.
An alternative; a different thing altogether.
A decision has been made and it is impossible to change it.
Focus on a problem the moment you are facing it, and not earlier.
Don't cross a bridge before you come to it.
Don't complain if you can't enforce your point of view.
Don't bark if you can't bite.
Don't work early in the morning and late into the evening as well.
Don't burn the candle at both ends.
An act of treachery, perpetrated on a previous partner in a deceit.
Refers to two people equally matched in wit or cunning.
Never judge something based on its outward appearance.
Don't judge a book by its cover.
Figuratively, one who takes a contrary position for the sake of testing an argument, or just to be perverse.
Someone who is basically good hearted but lacking social graces and respect for the law.
Someone who makes a wise judgement about something that has previously proven difficult to resolve.
A feeling of pessimism and despondency, often with regard to business or political prospects.
When you are separated from the person you love, your feelings are even stronger.
Distance makes the heart grow fonder.
Excellent - the absolute apex. In other contexts the word bollocks meaning testicles has a negative connotation.
A dead person cannot cause difficulties by revealing something that it would be preferable to conceal.
Success comes to those who deserve it least.
An ironic name for the imagined crime of being a black driver.
Very hot days during July and August.
Referring to the decisive moment at the very end of a close contest.
You must not be too confident that something will be successful.
Don't count your chickens before they're hatched.
A very small proportion of the whole.

A race between road vehicles - usually two vehicles over a quarter mile straight track and from a standing start. The race is essentially a competition to determine which vehicle has the greater acceleration.
An appreciation of what is fresh and new.
Dressed or displayed in an ostentatiously smart manner.
An outcome that is almost assured; a certainty.
Don't be ungrateful when you receive a gift.
Don't look a gift horse in the mouth.
Something that fails ignominiously to satisfy expectations; an anti-climax, a disappointment.
Diligence is the mother of good fortune.
Drink heavily, especially of alcoholic drink.
A conspicuously attractive but stupid blonde woman.
Originally a bag or sack with dirt in it. More recently an unkempt or slovenly person.
Nonsense; gibberish - a language one cannot understand.
A thought expressed in writing perhaps published in a newspaper can influence a large number of people.
(A) drop of ink may make a million think.
The bottom of the sea; the mythical resting place of drowned mariners.
Rape by an acquaintance during a social engagement.
Don't interfere when two people are having an argument.
Don't go between the tree and the bark.
Something or someone that comes in the nick of time to solve a difficulty, especially in works of fiction.
I don't want to discuss that.
Don't make a big deal out of a little thing.
Don't make a mountain out of a molehill.
The first line of a popular children's counting rhyme.
Wrong or unfair methods may be used if the result of the action is good.
Consume your own product in order to recognize its flaws.
Act submissively and apologetically, especially in admitting an error.
Music with an instant appeal but with little lasting significance.
Success comes to those who prepare well and put in effort.
An injunction to workers to 'down tools' come out on strike.
An important and obvious topic, which everyone present is aware of, but which isn't discussed, as such discussion is considered to be uncomfortable.
Hard work gives the best results.
Elbow grease is the best polish.
There is an explanation for everything.
The archetypal recipe for spells and enchantments.
Eye of newt and toe of frog, wool of bat and tongue of dog.
The 'turning of the tide' is literally the change of the tide from incoming to outgoing, or vice-versa. Normally the phrase is used to denote some change from a previously stable course of events.
Even at the turning of the tide.
Life is what you make it.
Every man is the architect of his own fortune.
The talking is over - there's no more to be said.
The supposed explanation that Sherlock Holmes gave to his assistant, Dr. Watson, when explaining deductions he had made.
What is suggested sounds easy, but it is more difficult to actually do it.
Conveying an untrue version of events by leaving out the important facts. A euphemism for lying, in short.
The least intelligent people are often the most talkative or noisy.
Empty vessels make the most noise.
A procedure whereby criminal suspects are sent for interrogation from one country to a second country, where less strict laws governing interrogation apply.
To egg someone on is to encourage them and urge them forward.
There is nothing bad that does not bring about something good.
Every cloud has a silver lining.
People like to listen to themselves talking.
Every ass likes to hear himself bray.
When one's financial situation deteriorates, friends tend to disappear.
The furthest reaches of the land.
Everyone's loyalty can be bought for a price.
Supposedly the last words of Julius Caesar. Literally 'And you, Brutus?'.
An incompetent person will be right sometimes.
Even a broken clock is right twice a day.
The label given to any fictional item that viewers have been induced into believing as real.
To get Enough is enough is to come off worst in a bargain or contest.
You must think of your own interests before the interests of others.
It is much better for you to go to bed early and to get up early in the morning.
Early to bed, and early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise.
There is no place like home.
Experience and knowledge result in better judgement.
Experience is the father of wisdom.
The notion that for every wrong done there should be a compensating measure of justice.
(An) eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth.
Everything in the garden is rosy.
The show is over - go home.
To set aside for a particular purpose.
A euphemism for the ruthless removal or killing of an ethnic or religious group from areas that have been taken over by opposing forces.
In effect; for all practical purposes.
Fools are often reckless in dangerous situations.
Fools rush in where angels fear to tread.
A perfect, joyful and simplistic ending to a story, like those often found in fairy tales.
An accomplished fact; an action which is completed before those affected by it are in a position to query or reverse it.
Accept the unpleasant consequences of one's actions.
Someone who is a friend to everyone makes none of them feel special.
(A) friend to all is a friend to none.
A remark or prediction that is likely to be proved wrong by events.
Nothing is achieved by empty words or flattery.

A scapegoat; one who takes on the responsibilities or workload of others. Here 'fall' is used with the criminal slang meaning of 'arrest' or 'period in prison'. More recently, it has also come to mean a person who is easily duped or outmanoeuvred.
Temporary hoarseness caused by phlegm in the back of the throat.
A real friend will tell you the truth.
(A) friend's eye is a good mirror.
Rowdy, boisterous, full of youthful energy.
Someone who is in a situation they are unsuited to.
Beard regrowth that darkens a man's features late in the day, following a morning shave.
Alluding to the alleged inherent weakness of character of women.
One should learn from one's mistakes.
Fool me once, shame on you; fool me twice, shame on me.
A seemingly insignificant thing that goes wrong can result in problems of enormous proportions.
For want of a nail the shoe is lost, for want of a shoe the horse is lost, for want of a horse the rider is lost.
A state of happiness based on false hope.
A stuffy or foolishly old-fashioned person.
To ascertain something; to deduce from the facts.

There is some uncertainty about the precise meaning of this phrase. Some use it to mean 'make a choice about what you intend to do'; others have it that it means 'either get to work in a productive manner or do something else and let someone else work'. The second meaning, which I favour, and which is more common, is similar in meaning to 'put up or shut up', or the 20th century US vulgarism 'shit or get off the pot'.
If you learn when to keep silent you will avoid trouble.
(A) fly will not get into a closed mouth.
Respond to an attack by using a similar method as one's attacker.
A faulty or sub-standard car. More widely, any poor effort.
At top speed; with maximum energy.
The most difficult part of an action is the beginning.
People can learn from their failures and be successful later on.
Fell off the back of a truck.
Knowing someone very well can lead to a lack of respect for them.
Fie, foh, fum, I smell the blood of an Englishman.
One's flesh and blood may refer to one's family, or may denote all mankind. It is also used to denote the living material of which people are mostly composed.
Attempting to revive an interest which has died out; engaging in fruitless effort.
A decision made before the evidence for it is known. An inevitable conclusion.
An evangelical call to believe in and spread the Christian faith.
If you miss an occasion, you can avail yourself of it another time.

Almost always it is the origin of a phrase or saying that requires the most research, the meaning being well understood. This phrase is interesting because there are various interpretations of its meaning.
(A) friend in need is a friend indeed.
A friend is more tolerant than a lover/partner/spouse?

Originally the term referred just to the USA see origin below, but now is understood to mean the most industrially developed, wealthy and powerful nations of the world. These countries are often referred to loosely as 'The West', although the First World certainly includes Japan and Australia.
Honest and straightforward, especially of business dealings.
Someone sympathetic toward a certain point of view without being a fully paid-up member of the club.
Trivial; worthless; only of interest to gullible people.
The first person in the line will be attended to first.
People show what they are really like by what they do, rather than by what they say.
Confession is the beginning of forgiveness.
Effort is necessary to keep a friendship alive.
Friendship is like money, easier made than kept.
This is a well-known as a quotation from Andy Warhol. It does derive from Warhol but his actual line was somewhat different - "In the future everybody will be world famous for fifteen minutes."
Progress from one success to another higher level of success.
To have had more than enough of something or someone, or to be bored with or tired of the same.
An introduction or way in to something, made in order that progress may be made later.
When an organization or state fails, it is the leadership that is the root cause.
(A) fish rots from the head down.
Properly conducted conditions for a game, giving all participants an equal chance. Also used more widely to mean fairness and justice in contexts other than games.
Idle people will quickly be forgotten by history.
Footprints on the sands of time are not made by sitting down.
An exchange of two things of equal value is a reasonable and honest trade.
To occupy oneself with unimportant matters and neglect priorities during a crisis.
An aggressive attack on prey by a group of sharks. The resulting boiling and bloody sea results in the sharks wildly attacking any creature nearby - even their own kind.
A disassociation from something - 'God forbid that I should... ' [do that thing].
A day of excitement or a circumstance of opportunity.
Jesus' words from the cross, asking forgiveness for those who put him to death. More widely, of course, the plea was for all humanity.
Forgive them for they know not what they do.
The fifth power in the land.
The name given to iron pyrites, which looks a little like gold but is worthless.
Infiltrators or collaborators with the enemy.
A symbol of honour and achievement.
Decide a course of action as you go along, using your own initiative and perceptions rather than a predetermined plan or mechanical aids.
Fly by the seat of one's pants.
Overly elaborate, swanky or pretentious - especially of dress. Also applied to people who act in that manner.
To fall from position of high esteem.
Excellent - especially of food. Known primarily as the slogan of the KFC food chain.
A colloquial expression, used to denote icy weather.
To put off deceitfully; to attempt to satisfy with something of inferior quality or something less than one has been led to expect.

A reference to the mythological figure Helen of Troy or some would say, to Aphrodite. Her abduction by Paris was said to be the reason for a fleet of a thousand ships to be launched into battle, initiating the Trojan Wars.
(The) face that launched a thousand ships.
Dishonest or treacherous behaviour; also violent conduct.
To resist; to keep someone or something from coming near.
Someone who slavishly follows fashion trends.
Commit suicide or offer your resignation.
Play to keep the winnings. Also, more generally, especially in America, 'in deadly earnest; in such a way that the result will stand'.
Full to the brim; packed tight.
There is an appropriate time for everything.
For every thing there is a season.
Haemorrhoids. Haemorrhoids -> piles -> Farmer Giles -> Farmers.
A small but irritating flaw that spoils the whole.
It's better to know who your real enemies are rather than trust someone who pretends to be a friend but is capable of stabbing you in the back.
False friends are worse than open enemies.
Alludes to the position of being able to freely observe a situation without being oneself noticed.
Talking is a long way from working, thus a halfway done paltry project is better than an unstarted ambitious project.
Fifty percent of something is better than one hundred percent of nothing.
Very rich, possibly having become so by unfair means.
A quotation from a work by John Donne, in which he explores the interconnectedness of humanity - see below.
Something which disappoints by failing to deliver anything of value, despite a showy beginning.
Using all of one's efforts; at top speed.
A derogatory term for a black person, especially one with fuzzy hair.
A property or item that is in need of repair and is offered for sale at a low price.
If a person hasn't matured by the age of 40, they never will.
(A) fool at forty is a fool forever.
Failing to plan is planning to fail.
From one place to another, haphazardly and to little purpose.
Any misfortune that would make life unlivable, especially rape or loss of virginity. The phrase was formerly a euphemism for rape.
A foolish person usually spends money carelessly.
(A) fool and his money are soon easily parted.
Inform on someone to the police.
To tackle a difficult problem boldly.
You will keep your friends if you avoid disputes over money.
Material assets are fleeting, but intellectual assets will basically stay with you for the rest of your life. Therefore, intellectual assets are much more worth than material ones.
Genius is largely the result of hard work, rather than an inspired flash of insight.
Genius is one percent inspiration, ninety-nine percent perspiration.
Trying to get everything will often result in not gaining anything.
If you know that you have done something wrong, you don't need anyone to tell you that you're guilty.
Drunk; by drinking gin or other alcoholic drink. Alternatively; enlivened.
A modern-day proverb, bemoaning the difficulty of finding a suitable male partner.
(A) good man is hard to find.
Faulty instructions will only result in faulty results.
Success comes to those who make a real effort to achieve it.
God helps those who help themselves.
Prepare for a battle or adopt a warlike stance.
Behave in a frenzied and violent manner.
An expression of pleasure on being rid of some annoyance - usually an individual.
Enough money, or the promise of it, will accomplish anything.
(A) golden key can open any door.
Don't concern yourself with something that's already in the past; accept it and move on to more productive pursuits.
Any peripheral and pointless device which is added to a product to make it appear to perform better.
To perform some act or adopt some opinion fully and thoroughly.
Severe traffic congestion, where backed-up traffic blocks movement on intersecting roads and progress is completely halted.
Jesus's response when tempted by the Devil.
Giving a good example is better than giving advice.
(A) good example is the best sermon.
An interjection or exclamation of surprise.
Make a bad start to a project or relationship.
Get off on the wrong foot.
To go wrong, to become overly excited or deranged.
No longer functional - a reference to a person who had died or an item that was broken.
Give someone enough time and freedom and they will get into trouble.
Give someone enough rope and they will hang themselves.
A person or animal who is used as the subject of an experiment.
Someone who helps another in need for compassionate motives and with no thought of reward.
Fail completely and be considered a flop by the public.
Go over like a lead balloon.
Engage with the basic facts or realities.
Beware of letting your competence lead you into overconfidence.
The abandonment of elderly relatives by their carers.
A good product does not need advertising: it will spread through word of mouth or by the sight of others using it.
Show no mercy or concession; in its original usage, show no mercy for a vanquished opponent.
Income can be lost if it is used carelessly.
Good management is better than good income.
To apply unnecessary ornament - to over embellish.
Originally 'doolally tap', meaning unbalanced state of mind.
All things are a potential source of profit or advantage.
To be 'going to hell in a handbasket' is to be rapidly deteriorating - on course for disaster.
Going to hell in a handbasket.
Once you have lost your reputation, it is very hard to regain it.
Give a dog a bad name and hang him.
Put oneself in an isolated or disadvantaged position in one's support of someone or something.
A proverbial saying which suggests that the ability to work is of greater benefit than a one-off handout.
Give a man a fish, and you feed him for a day; show him how to catch fish, and you feed him for a lifetime.
You sleep well when you have nothing to feel guilty about.
(A) good conscience is a soft pillow.
Join a conversation in which another is speaking continually and leaving little opportunity for others.
An exclamation of surprise or delight.
An ugly thing will remain ugly even if its appearance is taken care of.
(A) golden bit does not make the horse any better.
Accept your lot, but make the best out of it.
The generation of people born between the 1950s and early 1970s, who were anarchic and directionless.
Go very fast; in a vigorous manner.
If a task is carefully planned, there's a better chance that it will be well done.
(A) good beginning makes a good end.

Winning all that's on offer in a sports competition, e.g. all the tricks in a game of bridge, or the all the major competitions in a sport in a single year - especially associated with tennis and golf. More generally, any all-out achievement.
Annoy me; get on my nerves.
The glass ceiling is an unacknowledged, self-imposed barrier to workplace advancement, usually in regard to women or minority groups.
An exclamation - a euphemistic shortening of God's hooks the nails on the cross.
The process is in active existence; for example, 'The teams are on the pitch - the whistle blows - the game is afoot.'
Smartened up, in a showy or garish way.
Fly into a violent rage, especially when provoked by workplace stress.
Accept that a particular state of affairs is inevitable.
A good reputation is better than a good appearance.
(A) good name is better than a good face.
To die, or in the case of inanimate objects, to cease working.
Give someone an inch and they will take a mile or yard.
Large successful operations can begin in a small way.
Great oaks grow from small acorns.
"If you are patient, you will have what you desire."
Good things come to those who wait.
Young boys eat a lot / are often hungry.
(A) growing youth has a wolf in his belly.
An expression of disdain, along the same lines as 'get lost', 'go and play in the traffic', etc.
A name for the kind of weight-and-pendulum eight-day clock in a tall case, formerly in common use.
Begin a journey or a project.
Someone who is virtuous in a coy, smug or sentimental manner.
Gardens are not made by sitting in the shade.
GOLF - Gentlemen only, ladies forbidden. The phrase that is sometimes supposed to be the origin of the word golf.
Dependable men, of rank and honour. The phrase was adapted later to 'twelve good men and true', indicating the twelve originally all men, now both sexes of a criminal jury.
Finished with, as in thrown overboard.
A request to someone to stop behaving in a haughty and self-righteous manner.
If you share your grief, it will be easier to bear.
Ginger beer = queer, that is, homosexual.
When you have money you feel more cheerful and secure.
(A) heavy purse gives to a light heart.
Live in the present, not the past.
(A) happy heart is better than a full purse.
It's not good to do too many things at the same time.
He who is everywhere is nowhere.
Fame, and indeed life, is fleeting.
Here lies one whose name was writ in water.
Handle a situation, or a person or an object, delicately and gingerly.
A threat of a serious reprisal.
'Hard', that is, exceptional, legal cases aren't suitable as the source of generalised laws.
A type of suede shoes. Also, in the USA, a form of corn-bread fritter.
Unprovoked attacks on individuals made in order to record the event, and especially the victim's shock and surprise, on video phones.
A nonsense phrase with no real meaning as such, although it also sometimes used as a jovial greeting.
To repeatedly and boringly speak about a topic.
If you behave in a risky way, you are likely to have problems.
He who plays with fire gets burnt.
It's better to be in good health than to be rich.
If you take care of the important matters, everything else will fall into place.
(The) head and feet keep warm, the rest will take no harm.
Tocompare badly to an known authority - to be unfit even to hold a subordinate position.
In secret; in a clandestine manner.
A robust form of common sense believed to be found in poorly educated but shrewd people.
An indication that a piece of information was obtained via an informal contact.
A gruesome form of torture and, eventually, death by execution.
You call home the place where the people you love are.
Home is where the heart is.
To avoid committing oneself; to leave a means of retreat open.
Having a passionate nature, or being inclined to quick temper.
The full moon closest to the autumn equinox.
Literally, pay the devil what you owe him. Used figuratively to mean 'give back what you owe', either money or favours.
He will give the Devil his due.
A small measure of drink, intended to cure a hangover.
This little phrase has several meanings - an advance warning - being wide awake and alert - being the head of - a type is display screen.
If you are determined to do something you will find a way.
He who wills the end wills the means.
The person who waits too long loses the opportunity.
Get off to a brisk and successful start.
Stranded, without help or hope of recovery.
Behaviour is more important than appearance.
Have a vague intimation of; have a slight knowledge of.
One of Shakespeare's best known lines. The quotation is sometimes now repeated ironically when someone is is need of some unimportant item.
(A) horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse.
Excited, and/or turning cartwheels to demonstrate one's excitement.
A desperate person will go from place to place when they need to satisfy their needs.
(A) hungry wolf is fixed to no place.
Get to the precise point. Do or say something exactly right.
Hit the nail on the head.
A loud-mouthed but ineffectual upper class fool.
No real choice at all - the only options being to either accept what is offered or refuse it. The expression is effectively the same as 'take it or leave it'.
A happy person needs nothing more.
He has enough who is content.
Rigidly adhered to - without doubt or debate.
Rushing into a decision may cause mistakes that waste more time than would have been taken by proceeding more carefully.
In close pursuit of someone/something, or immediately after some event.
You can obtain more cooperation from others by being nice.
Honey catches more flies than vinegar.
Patience is more precious than intelligence.
(A) handful of patience is worth more than a bushel of brains.
However long the night, the dawn will break.
(A) house divided against itself cannot stand.
Hononyms are words that have the same pronunciation but different meaning, origin, or spelling.
Knowledge leads us to make choices.
He who know nothing doubts nothing.
Trickery - double dealing. Also, more recently, sexual shenanigans.
A sign, warning of bad things to come.
Have a dispute to take up with someone or, to have an ulterior motive/ to have private ends to serve.
Hell has no fury like a woman scorned.
A person who feels hatred does not see any qualities in the person he/she hates.
Hatred is as blind as love.
Injured by the device that you intended to use to injure others.
A disparaging name for the form of Christian religious observance which is informal, musical and spontaneous.
Typing by looking for characters on the keyboard individually.
A gesture of celebration in which two people slap palms with the hands held above above the head.
A hungry person is totally concentrated on their need for food and nothing else interests them.
Literal meaning - it is especially painful to raise an ungrateful child.
How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is to have a thankless child.
In chaotic and disorderly haste. Also the name of an English fairground attraction with a spiral slide.
Powerful and superior, or arrogantly affecting to be so.
It is easy to be prudent in hindsight.

High-flyers, sometimes spelled high-fliers, are people who have achieved notable success, especially those who have become successful more quickly than is normal. The term is also used to describe speculative stock that has reached a high price in a short time.
If you believe you can do something, you will be able to do it.
He can who believes he can.
He who laughs last laughs longest.
Here and there; to this place and that place.
It is important to respect the privacy of others.
He who wins in the end wins.
He laughs best who laughs last.
Hard rock music, usually electric guitar-based and always loud.
All food tastes good when you are hungry.
A shout of acclamation or agreement.
A feeling of anxiety, apprehension or illness.
To reject or to have nothing to do with.
The previously powerful are now reduced.
You should be grateful for something, even if it is not as much as you wanted.
Half a loaf is better than none.
The person who provides the money for something should control how it is spent.
He who pays the piper calls the tune.
A criticism of the teaching profession, portraying it as second best.
He who can, does; he who cannot, teaches.
Words or sayings that are in common use; names that are familiar to everyone.
It is often good to tell someone a harsh truth including yourself.; Don't lie to yourself.; Don't live in denial.
A glance made with partially lowered eyelashes. This usually indicates suspicion or hostility but may signal other emotions too.
A series of three consecutive successes, in sport or some other area of activity.
A favourite topic that one frequently refers to or dwells on; a fixation.
Having one's intentions divided; not fully committed; lacking zeal or courage.
Chaotic and disorderly; in jumbled confusion.
Originally a genuine report of a life-threatening fault. Now used humorously to report any kind of problem.
Translated from the Spanish - 'see you later'.
A supposed magical charm previously uttered by magicians. More recently a general term for trickery or magic.
Accept an accurate description of you, even if it is not flattering.
If the shoe fits, wear it.
It's better to give than to receive.
It the subject under discussion isn't difficult to understand.
To be in disgrace or out of favour.
The legal concept that the guilt of an accused person cannot be presumed and that they must be assumed to be innocent until proven otherwise.
When troubles come they come together.
It never rains but it pours.
You have many friends when you have no difficulties.
In times of prosperity friends are plentiful.
Don't express regret for something that has happened and cannot be remedied.
It's no use crying over spilt milk.
Astate of sheltered and unworldly intellectual isolation.
The most difficult time is just before the problem is solved.
It is always darkest before the dawn.
No matter how the outlook is things can always turn back. In other words you should not celebrate until you are 100% sure there is a reason to do so.
It ain't over till it's over.
If you let something intrusive enter your life, your life will become difficult.
If a camel gets his nose in a tent, his body will follow.
Virtually secured - as good as in one's possession.
A man of even limited ability has an advantage over a person who is less able.
In the land of the blind the one-eyed man is king.
I'll go to the foot of our stairs.
In a single moment, with no delay.

This expression indicates the intention of seeing a course of action through, regardless of what it may entail. It suggests that, if one is decided to do something, one may as well do it wholeheartedly.
In for a penny, in for a pound.
Faced with a dilemma - perplexed and uncertain what to do.
If you want a friend, be a friend.
In a state of being neglected and immobile, with no prospect of movement to a better place.
Just in time; at the precise moment.
When two people do something together, one will be the leader and the other will be the subordinate.
If two ride a horse, one must ride behind.
If you're in a hole, stop digging.
To be quickly and/or emphatically successful, usually in a sexual or romantic context.
In the same circumstances; facing the same predicament.
If something is working adequately well, leave it alone.
If it ain't broke, don't fix it.
The terminology used in the children's guessing game.
I spy with my little eye.
When you are busy working you avoid temptation.
(An) idle brain is the devil's workshop.
Stumped: Stuck - unable to proceed, often regarding being confounded by some intellectual puzzle.
In low spirits; feeling dull and drowsy.
Plants and grains will grow badly if there is no rain in early spring.
If in February there be no rain, 'tis neither good for hay nor grain.
I have not slept at all.
I have not slept one wink.
Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.
Possible interpretation: what you do not know causes no worry or sadness.
In a quandary or some other difficult position.
If you try to do two things at the same time, you will not succeed in doing either of them.
If you chase two rabbits, you will not catch either one.
An unseasonably warm, dry and calm weather, usually following a period of colder weather or frost in the late Autumn or in the Southern hemisphere, where the term is less common, the late Spring.
It came like a bolt from the blue.
Onewho gives a gift but later takes it back.
In a few words; concisely stated.
It is often costly to divorce someone.
Don't persist with a task if the pressure of it is too much for you. The implication being that, if you can't cope, you should leave the work to someone who can.
If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.
Nothing is irreversible until the final act is played out.
It ain't over till the fat lady sings.
Others will abuse you if you let them.
If you make yourself into a doormat, people will wipe their feet on you.
If you get distracted from your goals, someone else might beat you to them.
In a position where advance and retreat are both impossible; in a fix.
Avoid regrets by taking the time to think before speaking or acting angrily.
If you are patient in one moment of anger, you will avoid 100 days of sorrow.
Supposedly said by Oscar Wilde at Customs Control in New York, 1882.
I have nothing to declare but my genius.
People vary in character and abilities, and this is a good thing.
It takes all sorts to make a world.
Wishing alone is of no use; you must act as well.
If wishes were horses, then beggars would ride.
There is nothing bad that does not bring about something good.
It's an ill wind that blows no good.
If you trust before you try, you may repent before you die.
If one's will does not prevail, one must submit to an alternative.
If the mountain will not come to Muhammad...
The use of personal details of another in order to use their identity dishonestly; for example, in order to obtain money, credit etc. fraudulently.
With the inside on the outside.
I see you are ready and anxious to depart.
I see you stand like greyhounds in the slips.
In perfect condition, especially of health.
"I will kill you and am prepared to be hanged as a consequence", or "I will swing a punch at you".
Unbecoming of one's position - beneath one's dignity.
Display your feelings openly, for all to see.
I will wear my heart upon my sleeve.
A display of confidence in a particular outcome; for example, 'She's always late. If she gets that train I'll eat my hat'.
The full title of the popular 1940s BBC radio comedy - ITMA.
If the law is applied too late, there is no justice.
A manufacturing/delivery process where a minimum of goods are kept in stock. Items are planned to arrive precisely at the time they are required for use or despatch.
To reach the point in a TV series that denotes it is irretrievably past its best by introducing a ridiculous or otherwise unbelievable plot device or characterisation in order to boost ratings.
Some pleasant event in the future, which is never likely to materialize.
Someone ready and available at the time needed.
Built in a makeshift and insubstantial manner.
A conspicuously self-assured, carefree and brash young man; a 'chancer'.
Begin something before preparations for it are complete.
Join a growing movement in support of someone or something, often in an opportunist way, when that movement is seen to have become successful.
A man who can turn his hand to many things.
A toy consisting of a box containing a figure with a spring, which leaps up when the lid is raised.
Judgement has not yet been finalised on a particular subject; especially due to information being incomplete.
Favouritism where jobs or other benefits are given to friends and acquaintances.
That which is deserved. A reward for what has been done - good or bad.
Strive to match one's neighbours in spending and social standing.
Apply yourself conscientiously to your work.
Keep your nose to the grindstone.
Be prepared and save your resources until they are needed.
Warn many people by punishing a few.
Kill one to warn a hundred.
A person, usually a man, who comes to the aid of another, usually a woman, in a gallant and courteous manner.
A dainty little trinket or ornament.
Prevent, either a person or an event, from advancing nearer.
Words spoken, on his deathbed, by Admiral Horatio Nelson to Captain Thomas Hardy.

The skill of ball-juggling - to keep a ball in the air for as long as possible by bouncing it off any part of the body that is allowed in the rules of football, that is, any part except the hands and arms. Typically the ball is kept up using the feet and head.
Remove the favorite parts of your work.

This was a graffito, of unknown origin but used predominantly by members of the US and UK military and predominantly during WWII. It was often combined with an earlier cartoon image, known as Chad, although the two aren't related apart from that conjunction.
Do not start something that you cannot control; you may fail or cause damage.
Kindle not a fire you cannot put out.
To be experienced in or knowledgeable about a subject.
Remain cheerful in a difficult situation.
What you learn when you are young will be invaluable when your grow old.
Knowledge in youth is wisdom in age.
To understand what is happening in changing circumstances and to be able to anticipate the future.
Know which way the wind blows.
Get down to work and apply oneself earnestly to it.
'Katy or Katie bar the door' means take precautions; there's trouble ahead.
Remain resolute and unemotional in the face of adversity, or even tragedy.
Observe the avoidance of familiarity which is appropriate to one's position. Also, in more recent usage, to remain aloof and detached from another person or situation.
Publicly retell of one's sexual exploits, often with the aim of revenge or monetary gain.
To understand how to do something. To be acquainted with all the methods required.
It is easier to make progress or be successful if you are educated or possess a lot of information.
Be innocent of any wrongdoing; stay out of trouble.
Keep your hands clean / keep your nose clean.
Maintain a level of activity in and enthusiasm for a project.
This expression is usually part of the phrases 'a fine kettle of fish', 'a pretty kettle of fish' etc, which mean 'a muddle or awkward state of affairs'.
To 'know on which side your bread is buttered' is to be aware of which side of a conflict it is in your interests to be on.
Know on which side your bread is buttered.
To survive. The phrase is most often used specifically to refer to earning sufficient money to keep oneself alive.
Remain cheerful - keep your head held high.
Say nothing - especially in circumstances where saying the wrong thing may get you into trouble.
If you are kind to someone, they will return your kindness.
Do not destroy the source of your good fortune.
Kill not the goose that lays the golden egg.
Here's a list of Latin phrases and sayings that are used in English often enough to have become part of the language.
A lot; as in 'hurts like the dickens'.
This proverbial saying means 'be careful, children are listening'.
Do not hold on to your anger for more than one day.
Let not the sun go down on your wrath.
The notion that simplicity and clarity lead to good design.
To transform a faulty object or venture into something that works effectively.
Play the fool, in a childish or careless manner.
Feeling euphoric and well-disposed towards those around you - induced by the use of drugs, notably Ecstasy methylenedioxymethamphetamine.
Let the cat out of the bag.
If you deal with a minor problem quickly, it will not become a major issue.
(A) little fire is quickly trodden out.
Abandoned in a difficult position without help.
A euphemistic way of expressing the benefits of sex.
(A) little of what you fancy does you good.
Learn the basics of any subject first.
Learn to walk before you run.
I was told by a private or secret source.
A reference to homosexual love, although Oscar Wilde denied this in his defense of the charge of gross indecency.
(The) love that dare not speak its name.
If you lose something you lament, if you find something you keep it.
Unguarded talk may give useful information to the enemy.
This was said by combative UK Labour politician Dennis Healey on being criticized by the mild mannered Tory minister Geoffrey Howe in the UK House of Commons in June 1978.
Like being savaged by a dead sheep.
Encourage many ideas from many sources.
Really wealthy people do not talk about money.
The good life, full of pleasure and indulgence.
A person in love does not see the faults of the person he/she loves.
Living well; fed by abundant crops.
Living off the fat of the land.
'Beer and skittles' is shorthand for a life of indulgence spent in the pub.
Life's not all beer and skittles.
Lose face - Be humiliated; lose one's reputation.
A bad event can more easily be forgotten if you do not talk about it.
Avoid interfering in a situation which is currently stable.
To laugh coarsely or loudly, especially at the discomfort of others.
A person or thing that isn't properly able to function, especially one that was previously proficient.
Telling one lie will lead you to tell another one.
Allow the unpleasant things that have happened in the past to be forgotten.
One's varied interests are kept separate.
(The) left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing.
A son's character can be expected to resemble his father's.
To beat the living daylights out of someone is to beat them severely, to the point where they lose consciousness.
A figure or object of ridicule and laughter.
Life begins to be better in one's middle age.
Let others do whatever they want as long as it does not hurt anyone.
The final additional small burden that makes the entirety of one's difficulties unbearable.
(The) last straw that broke the camel's back.
Irresistibly and dangerously attracted to something or someone.
Like a moth to a flame.
Workundertaken for the pleasure of it or for the benefit of a loved one.
Used to highlight and ridicule snobbish forms of behaviour or speech.
A description of the British soldiers of WWI.
The less you talk about an incident, the more easily it will be forgotten.
Like a chicken with its head cut off.
Old, especially of horses or people.
An unpredictable person or thing, liable to cause damage if not kept in check by others.
A small amount of knowledge can mislead people into thinking that they are more expert than they really are.
(A) little knowledge is a dangerous thing.
We should not try to control our destiny.
Let the chips fall where they may.
An introduction, often on stage, indicating that the person announced last is no less important than those introduced earlier.
Do not lend or borrow money.
Living after the time you would have expected to have died.
An extreme standard of comparison; for example, "It rained like billy-o; we were all soaked through."
A sporting contest between rivals from the same district. Often referring to football soccer matches.
In a listless, languid manner; without interest.
(A) loveless life is a living death.
Keepout of sight; bide one's time.

The origins of many English phrases are unknown. Nevertheless, many people would say that they know the source of this one. It is widely attributed to Marie-Antoinette 1755-93, the Queen consort of Louis XVI. She is supposed to have said this when she was told that the French populace had no bread to eat.
An unusual event is not likely to occur again in exactly the same circumstances.
Lightning never strikes in the same place twice.
An exclamation, on drawing others attention to something. Used especially to to announce things that are considered startling or important. The phrase is often written with an exclamation mark.
Education is something that you keep forever.
Learning is a treasure that will follow its owner everywhere.
In an unconcerned manner - unaware of the impending catastrophe.
Many incremental changes will after some time transform what is pathetic into something grand.
Little by little and bit by bit.
If you divide a task into small parts, it become easier to do.
A cursory effort, for instance at painting or tidying up. It alludes to the perfunctory washing performed by children.
Behave in a free or uninhibited manner.
People who do not tell the truth must be careful to remember what they say.
The notion that things cannot change their innate nature.
Literal meaning, that is, a living person of considerable fame.
Response to a request to do something that seems too petty to waste valuable time on.
A notional place characterized by fantasy, self-absorption and blissful lack of touch with reality.
Said of an unpleasant outcome that one has no choice but to accept - one can either endure it willingly or endure it with suffering.
Said of the application of the law that is contrary to common sense.
Fair competition, where no advantage is shown to either side.

Prepared for burial. The phrase has also been used to mean 'show something in the best possible light'. There are also reports of its use as meaning 'to criticize or condemn', but I can't confirm that usage.
It is always the end of something that feels the most difficult.
(The) longest mile is the last mile home.
A literary genre in which magical features and storylines appear and are accepted as everyday reality.
Women give a house its comfort and character.
Men make houses, women make homes.
Physical nourishment is not sufficient for a healthy life; man also has spiritual needs.
Man does not live by bread alone.
Akindred spirit - someone I can agree with.
(A) man who is his own lawyer has a fool for a client.
Sharing work makes the task easier.
A great deal of fuss over nothing of importance.
When people are sad they often like others to feel sad too.
Whatever one does in one's life is one's own responsibility and cannot be changed.
A person's character is judged by the type of people with whom they spend their time.
(A) man is known by the company he keeps.
Obtain kudos from apparently willingly doing something that one was in fact couldn't avoid doing. It is also used to mean 'submit with good grace'.
A literal meaning; that the truth is often found in comic utterances.
Many a true word is spoken in jest.
A person is judged on what he/she actually does, not on what they say they will do.
(A) man is judged by his deeds, not by his words.
To minister is to serve, or act as a subordinate agent. So a ministering angel is a kind-hearted person, providing help and comfort.
(A) ministering angel shall my sister be.
A good memory is very precious.
Memory is the treasure of the mind.
Re-establish good relations with people one has disagreed with.
A sedative or sometimes in the US a purgative drug surreptitiously slipped into someone's drink.
Said in reply to someone who has reported doing something that is considered to be obviously foolish.
Note and reflect upon something in order to thoroughly assimilate it.
If you get married too quickly, you may spend your whole life regretting it.
Marry in haste, repent as leisure.
A miss is a miss regardless the distance.
(A) miss by an inch is a miss by a mile.
A rhyme used to decide who starts a darts match.
Something or someone that one finds pleasing.
To 'mull something over' is to turn it over in one's mind, in a reflective way.
A living arrangement comprising three people not all of the same sex in a sexual relationship. Alternatively, a sexual liaison between such a group of people.
Delicious; tasty enough to make you salivate.
No matter how someone dresses, it's the same person underneath.
(A) monkey in silk is a monkey no less.
Carry on with what you are doing - it will give me an excuse to behave badly.
The weather at the beginning of March is stormy and at the end is mild.
March comes in like a lion and goes out like a lamb.
A [narrow] miss is as bad as a wide miss - they are both misses.
(A) miss is as good as a mile.
I have more than enough for my needs.
People have a constant desire to possess more.
(The) more you have, the more you want.
The 'offer' being 'do as I say or I'll kill you'.
Make him an offer he can't refuse.
Things often don't turn out as you have planned.
Literal meaning, alluding to the variety in qualities of humankind.
Many are called but few are chosen.
The diarrhoea spelled in America as diarrhea that is often suffered by tourists when travelling to foreign parts.
Nonsense, especially meaningless speech and often associated with spurious religious ritual.
Possibly: a person's manners show their origins.
Many small amounts accumulate to make a large amount.
Many a little makes a mickle.
Makes your hair stand on end.
The so-called law is usually expressed as 'If anything can go wrong, it will'.
Something unadventurous or inoffensive; opting to go neither one way or the other.
People of energetic demeanour, who initiate change and influence events.
If you have money you can make more money.

The condition of having a body weight high enough to pose a severe risk to health. This is informally measured as having a body weight which is more than twice the optimum. It is indicated more precisely by a 'body mass index' of 40 or over BMI = the weight in kilograms divided by the square of height in metres.
Arrive at a final decisive contest.
May you experience much disorder and trouble in your life.
May you live in interesting times.
A much vaunted discovery, which later turns out to be illusory or worthless.
